author: Chainwire
title: Decentralized Storage Protocol Walrus Launches Public Testnet
text:
Palo Alto, United States, 17th October 2024, Chainwire Palo Alto, United States, October 17th, 2024, Chainwire
Akord, a web3 platform for securing and managing data, also begins its migration to Walrus Protocol
Mysten Labs, the web3 infrastructure company, today announced that following a successful Devnet, Walrus Protocol, a decentralized storage network, has launched its public Testnet.
Walrus Protocol stores and delivers large data files, including rich media content, audio files, video, images, PDFs and more, from any web2 or web3-based source. These large files, known as blobs, are stored quickly and efficiently by Walrus, whose storage is resilient, scalable, programmable, and secure. Walrus's public Testnet, and its Testnet token, WAL, are served by Sui as the coordination layer. Sui provides a dedicated management architecture for Walrus to store its global state and metadata offering speedy consensus, composability, and the opportunity to integrate storage into smart contracts on Sui. Walrus's Testnet launch will include:
API endpoints that support deletable blobs, meaning data can be deleted.
Dedicated Walrus explorer, allowing users to search data quickly and comprehensively, built by Stakestab Inc, maker of Suiscan & Blockberry API Platform.
Full tokenomics ecosystem for the Walrus token, WAL, including epoch management, staking and unstaking, and rewards, as well as the WAL token faucet for developers.
WAL staking app, developed by Mysten Labs.
"As blockchain projects aim to become more decentralized, it has been apparent for quite some time that a decentralized storage network was needed for networks of all kinds, L1s and L2s, to support end-user applications with rich media and larger storage needs," said George Danezis, Chief Scientist and Co-Founder at…
Chainwire

author: EP
title: Boeing va a la huelga por primera vez en 16 años
text: Secciones Servicios Destacamos EP Viernes, 13 de septiembre 2024, 11:46 Necesitas ser suscriptor para acceder a esta funcionalidad. Opciones para compartir El sindicato de los trabajadores de Boeing en en la región de Seattle (EE.UU.) ha convocado una huelga por primera vez en 16 años y ha rechazado la oferta del fabricante para subir un 25% los salarios. Según recoge DPA, el 94,65% de los trabajadores votaron que no a la oferta que lanzó Boeing para evitar los paros, que contemplaba una subida salarial del 25% en cuatro años, mejorar en las coberturas sanitarias y las jubilaciones, dado que el sindicato IAM había pedido inicialmente un incremento del 40% en los salarios. Además, el 96% apoyó la convocatoria de huelga. La huelga ha comenzado a las 00.00 hora local de este viernes para unos 30.000 trabajadores. Los representantes sindicales han señalado en una rueda de prensa recogida por 'Bloomberg' que los puntos del acuerdo no eran lo suficientemente buenos y que la oferta no compensaba los 16 años de estancamiento salarial, el aumento de los gastos sanitarios y la deslocalización de miles de empleos sindicales. Por su parte, Boeing ha emitido un comunicado en el que muestra su compromiso para restablecer la relación con los trabajadores y el sindicato, además de volver a la mesa para alcanzar un nuevo acuerdo. Boeing atraviesa una crisis de reputación, de seguridad y económica desde 2019, cuando dos aviones 737 MAX sufrieron accidentes fatales. Tras esto, se han producido otros incidentes, como la caída de una parte del fuselaje de un avión de Alaska Airlines a principios de este año. Publicidad Publicidad Te puede interesar [ La honestidad rock del mejor Calamaro ](https://www.laverdad.es/culturas/musica/honestidad-rock-mejor-calamaro-20240920072437-nt.html#vca=voc-recirc&vso=lasprovincias) La Verdad Publicidad Publicidad Comentar es una ventaja exclusiva para suscriptores ¿Ya eres suscriptor? Necesitas ser suscriptor para poder votar. Reporta un error en esta noticia

author: Airman
title: Fussa native receives AF Security Forces of the Year award | Stripes Japan
text: [ Spotlight! ](https://japan.stripes.com/spotlight/) Fussa native receives AF Security Forces of the Year award 374th Airlift Wing Public Affairs May 6, 2024 YOKOTA AIR BASE, Japan -- Fussa native Tatsuya Hara, 374th Security Forces Squadron chief of civilian defense, was named the Air Force Outstanding Security Forces Flight-level Civilian Supervisor of the Year due to his efforts at Yokota Air Base. This Air Force-level award is bestowed upon individuals who have made outstanding contributions to the defense and security mission of the U.S. Air Force and its allies. It recognizes civilian employees who have demonstrated exceptional leadership, dedication, innovation and performance in supporting the Air Force’s mission. Growing up in Fussa and in close proximity to Yokota Air Base, the military presence in Fussa sparked Hara’s interest in getting involved with the base. “The base held friendship festivals every year and I went every time,” said Hara. “It’s been my dream to work here since I was a kid.” In 1990, Hara’s dream had come true when he started working on the base as a civilian guard for the security forces squadron. The 374th SFS is responsible for maintaining a safe and secure environment for personnel, resources, and operations at Yokota Air Base. Hara has since worked for the unit for over 30 years and now supervises over 80 Japanese civilian guards. “Hara-san’s the expert at security for the friendship festival event,” said Chief Master Sgt. Brandy Collins, 374th Security Forces Squadron senior enlisted leader. “You’ll see him out there and he will be laser-focused about business.” Friendship Festival is an annual event where Yokota Air Base opens to the general public, offering static displays of numerous aircraft, live performances and a multitude of U.S.-Japan military readiness. Each year welcomes over a hundred thousand people to the airfield. While off duty, Hara had spent his free time volunteering on multiple occasions through organizing a sports day for two local elementary schools, leading 105 parent volunteers, planning 12 events, and even procuring $1,400 for prizes. “His years of experience, continuity and dedication to volunteering his free time contributed to his nomination for this award,” said Collins. “Anytime you see him mentioned on social media there are comments about how many Airmen’s lives he’s influenced and the respect he’s earned.” To Hara, while even the civilian guard job can be difficult, his leadership has always supported his team and he attributes their support as a driving factor for his success and award nomination. The Air Force Outstanding Security Forces Flight-level Civilian Supervisor of the Year award serves as a testament of Hara’s contributions as a Japanese civilian partner, whose expertise and dedication play a vital role in achieving the 374th Airlift Wing’s shared objectives to ensure the security of a free and open Indo-Pacific region.

author: VNExplorer
title: Michigan Four-Star Cornerback Departs Program Just Days Before College Football Playoff
text:
usatsi_21719188-1
Not even Michigan, the No. 1 seed in the College Football Playoff, is immune to losing players to the transfer portal.
With just four days until the Wolverines’ Rose Bowl game vs. No. 4 Alabama, Jim Harbaugh’s football program has suffered a pretty significant loss.
Cameron Calhoun, a former four-star cornerback recruit in the 2022 cycle, is leaving the program to enter the NCAA transfer portal. Calhoun was the No. 33 overall cornerback in his class, per 247Sports. The 6-foot, 173-pound defensive back and Cincinnati native appeared in two games for Michigan against UNLV and Bowling Green.
Calhoun likely wanted to stay on Harbaugh’s team for the rest of the College Football Playoff experience. But the college football calendar isn’t kind to players on CFP teams who may want to play elsewhere next season.
Michigan takes on Alabama in the Rose Bowl on Jan. 1 at 5 p.m. ET. The winner advances to the national title where it’ll play the winner of Washington vs. Texas.
It’ll be interesting, meanwhile, to see where Calhoun ends up playing next season.

Maestros de Telesecundaria convocan a paro de labores por adeudo salarial
Alicia Limón | Plano Informativo | 26/03/2025 | 17:14
Ciudad Fernández, SLP.-
Maestros de educación Telesecundaria han convocado a un paro de labores para el próximo lunes 31 de marzo,
debido al incumplimiento en el pago del adeudo salarial que se mantiene con ellos.
Representantes sindicales expresaron su pesar por la situación, señalando que durante más de un año se ha esperado y confiado en que las autoridades oficiales y sindicales resolverían el tema de la homologación salarial.
Sin embargo, lamentaron que los maestros han sido sistemáticamente engañados.
La falta de respuesta a las necesidades de los maestros de Telesecundaria ha sido generalizada, incluyendo la inacción de los representantes sindicales estatales, quienes, según se denuncia, no han defendido a la base magisterial.
Ante esta situación, el llamado al sindicato será enérgico.
Por este motivo, se ha hecho un llamado a los maestros de Telesecundaria a unirse y manifestarse con firmeza en la capital del Estado. Esta acción se debe a la proximidad del cambio de representantes y al temor de que,
si el pago no se realiza antes de este proceso, los maestros no reciban lo que les corresponde.
Los maestros reconocen la dificultad de mantener esta situación, pero están decididos a buscar una participación masiva para demostrar su fuerza y exigir el pago de sus derechos.

author: @UnioneSarda
title: Discariche abusive e "lancio del sacco" Contro gli incivili la telecamera non basta  - L'Unione Sarda.it
text:
Le telecamere non fermano gli incivili. Accade in via del Lentisco, al confine tra Pirri e Monserrato, dove il “lancio del sacco” prosegue nonostante l’introduzione della videosorveglianza. All’incrocio con via delle Spighe, sotto l’occhio di due diverse telecamere, continuano ad accumularsi rifiuti, anche ingombranti. I residenti delle case antistanti, stufi di convivere con il degrado, non sanno più a che santo votarsi. Amareggiata la presidente della Municipalità, Maria Laura Manca. «Queste azioni di abbandono purtroppo non si fermano», osserva, «dispiace il poco senso civico, evidentemente è necessario intensificare i controlli e le azioni di sensibilizzazione per contrastare quella che ormai è diventata una triste abitudine».
E non va meglio in via Bosco Cappuccio, a San Michele, dove a meno di 48 ore da un intervento del Comune finalizzato a liberare il marciapiede destro da una distesa di rottami, il passaggio pedonale risulta nuovamente ostruito, nello stesso punto, da una catasta di assi di legno, scarti edilizi e sacchi ricolmi di rifiuti domestici. Una battaglia contro i mulini a vento, insomma. «Le telecamere qui non ci sono e ci auguriamo che le mettano», auspica Silvio Pinna, che abita a pochi passi, «fra l’altro è inverosimile che tutti quei materiali siano stati abbandonati da un residente. Via Bosco Cappuccio è una strada di passaggio, più probabile che sia stato qualcuno arrivato da fuori col furgone. Non sarebbe la prima volta».Degrado anche tra via Sarrabus e via delle Langhe, quasi di fronte al cimitero di San Michele. In una vasta area libera si è formato uno stagno maleodorante e infestato da zanzare, sulle cui sponde si può “ammirare” una discarica a cielo aperto con numerosi pneumatici. Una bomba ecologica a breve distanza dalle abitazioni.
RIPRODUZIONE RISERVATA

author: NewsBreak Original
title: Some Cleveland homeowners still dealing with aftermath of summer storms
text:
By Katie Ussin ,
4 hours ago The weather event of the year for Northeast Ohio was this summer when five EF-1 tornadoes, a macroburst, and widespread straight-line wind damage occurred across our region.
Nanci Sudano, a resident of Cleveland's West Side, grew up in the house she once again calls home. She has wonderful memories of a place that now looks different.
"A lot has changed," said Sudano. "It’s no longer what it used to be.
Her neighborhood got an unrequested remodel, or razing of sorts in spots, when severe weather came through Northeast Ohio on the afternoon of Aug. 6, 2024. Sudano still has not fully recovered from the damages incurred four months ago and said she had never seen damage like that before from a natural disaster.
"Only on TV," she recalled.
I previously reported on the aftermath of Cleveland’s West Side near Edgecliff Avenue and Warren Road. I kept in touch with Sudano after reporting the damage to the area that day.
Video News 5 recorded that day behind Sudano's home showed the damage; almost a dozen decades-old trees were uprooted in a row, nearly every home on her block needed a new roof, fences were flattened, and garages were gone.
Storms tear through Northeast Ohio, leaving hundreds of thousands without power RELATED: Storms tear through Northeast Ohio, leaving hundreds of thousands without power
"We were really hit hard, but thank God no one got hurt,” Sudano said.
That was the silver lining. But four months later, Sudano is still not whole.
"It has been, um, difficult,” she said.
Red tape with insurance has caused some delays in fixing property damage.
"You really have to look at what your insurance entails," said Sudano about what she's learned.
But things are now moving along, and she feels hopeful. Sudano has roofers and builders lined up to reconstruct her garage.
"Just waiting for our turn," she said.
Despite what the storm wiped away, something of value was also given. Destruction can build perspective.
“Forget about the silly things we get upset about and just hold on to what’s important," Sudano said.
While her view out back may look different now, she said it’s the people and community there who make it feel like home— and that hasn’t changed.
"I'm just really thankful and grateful," she said.
Sudano mentioned the importance of double-checking your insurance policy coverage.
Andrew Kobak, president of Cleveland Public Adjusters, also gave advice. He told News 5 that many people he talked with who had major damage from the severe weather event were underinsured.
"I want people to look at their policy and look at the dwelling coverage, that’s what you have on your house or your building coverage if you have a commercial building," Kobak said. "Look at the policy limit, multiply your square footage by $200 or $250 per square foot and make sure that number equals that. So, if it’s a 2,000 sq ft home I think you should half-a-million-dollars in coverage on that house."
Kobak said home values are going up, and so are building costs. And while this might raise your premiums a bit, he said it’s nominal compared to what it could save you in a disaster like a tree crashing into your home or a large fire.
He advised people to check their policy, do that formula, and talk with their insurance agent if they have questions or need to make adjustments.
The Ohio Emergency Management Agency shared figures submitted to them from the Aug. 6:
Ashtabula, $89,688 Cuyahoga, $10,971,344.32 Lake, $323,562.48 Lorain, $579,935.53 Summit, $1,541,401.63 These are local government costs for debris operations, emergency services, and repairs to damaged infrastructure and facilities.
These numbers are still just estimates. So, the final amount will vary. The Ohio EMA said the state covers 75% of the actual costs.

author: Daniel Schwartz
title: Salesforce Einstein Review 2024 | Is it the Best Analytics Software?
text:
In this competitive business environment, leveraging data for strategic decisions is crucial. Salesforce Einstein is an AI-powered analytics platform designed to help businesses unlock insights through predictive analytics, natural language processing (NLP), and machine learning (ML). This Salesforce Einstein review and guide will walk you through the platform as we explore how it functions, its setup process, pricing, advantages, disadvantages, and its competitors. With this comprehensive review aim to help businesses determine if Salesforce Einstein is the right analytics solution for their needs.
What is Salesforce Einstein? Salesforce Einstein is an artificial intelligence (AI) platform embedded within the Salesforce ecosystem, designed to bring advanced AI capabilities to customer relationship management (CRM). Launched in 2016, Salesforce Einstein integrates predictive analytics, machine learning, and natural language processing to provide actionable insights and automate complex business processes.
Einstein empowers users by enhancing their CRM with smart features like predictive lead scoring, automated data discovery, personalized customer experiences, and more. These capabilities enable businesses to anticipate customer needs, optimize operations, and make data-driven decisions with greater confidence.
One of the key strengths of Salesforce Einstein is its seamless integration with the Salesforce platform . This integration allows users to leverage existing Salesforce data and processes, enhancing them with AI-driven insights without needing to switch between multiple tools. Einstein’s user-friendly interface and robust features make it accessible to users of varying technical expertise, from data scientists to business analysts.
Overall, Salesforce Einstein represents a significant advancement in the CRM space, providing businesses with the tools to transform raw data into meaningful insights and automate decision-making processes.
How Does Salesforce Einstein Work? Salesforce Einstein functions by embedding AI directly into the Salesforce platform, enhancing its CRM capabilities with advanced analytics and automation. Here’s a breakdown of its core functionalities:
Predictive Analytics Einstein leverages predictive analytics to forecast future trends and behaviors. For example, predictive lead scoring helps sales teams prioritize leads that are most likely to convert. By analyzing historical data and identifying patterns, Einstein can provide scores that indicate the likelihood of a lead becoming a customer.
Machine Learning Machine learning algorithms in Einstein automatically learn from data and improve over time. This allows businesses to create models that can predict outcomes, identify opportunities, and automate processes. For instance, Einstein Discovery uses machine learning to analyze data, uncover insights, and suggest actionable recommendations.
Natural Language Processing (NLP) Einstein uses NLP to understand and interpret human language , enabling features like sentiment analysis, chatbots, and voice recognition. Einstein Language, for instance, can categorize text into specific categories and determine the sentiment behind customer messages, helping businesses respond more effectively.
Automation Einstein automates routine tasks, freeing up time for more strategic activities. Features like Einstein Bots enable automated customer service interactions, while Einstein Voice allows users to interact with Salesforce using voice commands. Automation helps improve efficiency and ensures consistent execution of tasks.
Integration with Salesforce Einstein integrates seamlessly with other Salesforce products, such as Sales Cloud, Service Cloud, and Marketing Cloud. This integration allows businesses to leverage their existing Salesforce data, enhancing it with AI-driven insights without the need for complex data migrations or additional tools.
User-Friendly Interface Einstein’s intuitive interface makes it accessible to users with varying levels of technical expertise. Dashboards and visualizations simplify complex data, making insights easily understandable and actionable. Users can customize their views and create personalized reports to suit their specific needs.
By combining these functionalities, Salesforce Einstein enhances the overall CRM experience, enabling businesses to derive more value from their data and automate key processes.
How to Set Up an Account on Salesforce Einstein Setting up an account on Salesforce Einstein is a straightforward process, designed to integrate seamlessly with existing Salesforce environments. Here’s a step-by-step guide to help you get started:
Step 1: Salesforce Environment Ensure you have a Salesforce environment. If you don’t have one, visit the Salesforce website and sign up for a Salesforce account. Depending on your needs, you can choose from various editions, including Sales Cloud, Service Cloud, and Marketing Cloud.
Step 2: Enable Einstein Once your Salesforce environment is set up, navigate to the Salesforce AppExchange. Search for “Salesforce Einstein” and select the components relevant to your business, such as Einstein Analytics, Einstein Discovery, or Einstein Voice. Follow the instructions to install and enable these components in your Salesforce org.
Step 3: Configure Einstein Settings After enabling Einstein, configure its settings to align with your business needs. This involves setting up user permissions, defining data access, and configuring preferences for features like predictive lead scoring and automated insights. Salesforce provides detailed guides and support to assist with this configuration.
Step 4: Data Integration Einstein relies on data from your Salesforce environment to generate insights. Ensure that your Salesforce data is accurate and up-to-date. Import any additional data sources as needed, and integrate them into your Salesforce environment. This step is crucial for ensuring that Einstein can leverage all relevant data for analysis.
Step 5: Train Machine Learning Models For features like predictive analytics and machine learning, Einstein may require an initial training period where it analyzes historical data to build predictive models. Monitor this process and make any necessary adjustments to ensure that the models are accurately capturing the relevant patterns and trends.
Step 6: Customize Dashboards and Reports Customize Einstein dashboards and reports to suit your specific business needs. Create visualizations and reports that provide the insights you require, and set up automated alerts and notifications for key metrics and events. This customization ensures that you can quickly access the most important information.
Step 7: Monitor and Optimize Once Einstein is set up and running, continuously monitor its performance and the accuracy of its predictions. Make adjustments as needed to optimize its functionality. Utilize Salesforce’s support and resources to troubleshoot any issues and maximize the value of Einstein’s capabilities.
Setting up Salesforce Einstein involves a series of steps that integrate AI-powered analytics seamlessly into your existing Salesforce environment. With proper configuration and data integration, you can start leveraging advanced insights and automation to enhance your business processes.
What is the Pricing of Salesforce Einstein? Salesforce Einstein’s pricing varies based on the specific components and features you choose to implement. Here’s a detailed breakdown of the pricing structure:
Einstein Analytics Cost: Pricing starts at $75 per user per month. Features: Includes advanced analytics capabilities, customizable dashboards, and AI-driven insights. Suitable for businesses looking to enhance their data analysis capabilities within Salesforce. Einstein Discovery Cost: Pricing starts at $150 per user per month. Features: Provides automated data discovery, predictive analytics, and actionable recommendations. Ideal for businesses seeking deeper insights and automated decision-making tools. Einstein Voice Cost: Pricing is available upon request. Features: Enables voice-activated interactions with Salesforce, voice-based data entry, and automated voice insights. Useful for businesses that require hands-free operation and voice-driven processes. Einstein Prediction Builder Cost: Pricing starts at $75 per user per month. Features: Allows users to create custom AI models to predict outcomes, score leads, and more. Suitable for businesses needing tailored predictive analytics. Einstein Bots Cost: Pricing starts at $50 per user per month. Features: Provides automated customer service interactions through chatbots. Ideal for businesses looking to enhance customer support with AI-driven automation. Einstein Vision and Language Cost: Pricing is available upon request. Features: Offers image recognition and natural language processing capabilities. Useful for businesses that need advanced AI for visual data and text analysis. Customer Feedback on Pricing Customer feedback on Salesforce Einstein’s pricing is mixed. Many users appreciate the robust features and the value they bring to their business operations. However, some small and medium-sized businesses find the costs high, especially when integrating multiple Einstein components. The pricing model may be more suitable for larger enterprises with substantial budgets for advanced analytics.
Salesforce Einstein Features and Benefits Chart To provide a clear comparison, here’s a chart highlighting the features and benefits of Salesforce Einstein:
Feature Benefits Predictive Analytics Forecast future trends and behaviors Machine Learning Automate data analysis and decision-making Natural Language Processing Understand and interpret human language Automation Save time by automating routine tasks Integration with Salesforce Leverage existing data and processes User-Friendly Interface Simplify complex data with intuitive dashboards Voice-Activated Interaction Interact with Salesforce using voice commands Salesforce Einstein Benefits Chart – ArticlesBase.com What are the Advantages of Salesforce Einstein? Salesforce Einstein offers numerous advantages that make it a valuable tool for businesses looking to leverage AI for enhanced decision-making and process automation. Here are some of the key benefits:
Seamless Integration with Salesforce Einstein integrates seamlessly with the Salesforce platform, allowing businesses to leverage their existing Salesforce data and processes. This integration ensures that users can enhance their CRM capabilities without needing additional tools or complex data migrations.
Advanced Predictive Analytics Einstein provides robust predictive analytics capabilities, helping businesses forecast future trends and behaviors. Features like predictive lead scoring enable sales teams to prioritize leads that are most likely to convert, improving sales efficiency and effectiveness.
Automated Insights and Recommendations Einstein uses machine learning to analyze data and provide automated insights and recommendations. This helps businesses identify opportunities, optimize operations, and make data-driven decisions with greater confidence.
Natural Language Processing (NLP) Einstein’s NLP capabilities enable businesses to understand and interpret human language, facilitating sentiment analysis, chatbots, and voice recognition. These features enhance customer interactions and improve response times.
User-Friendly Interface Einstein’s intuitive interface makes it accessible to users of varying technical expertise. Dashboards and visualizations simplify complex data, making insights easily understandable and actionable.
Time-Saving Automation Einstein automates routine tasks, freeing up time for more strategic activities. Automated customer service interactions, voice-activated data entry, and predictive analytics reduce the workload and improve efficiency.
Strong Community and Support Salesforce offers extensive documentation, tutorials, and a strong community of users and developers. This support network helps users maximize the value of Einstein’s capabilities and troubleshoot any issues.
What are the Disadvantages of Salesforce Einstein? While Salesforce Einstein offers numerous advantages, there are some drawbacks to consider. Here are some of the key disadvantages:
High Cost One of the primary criticisms of Salesforce Einstein is its cost. The pricing can be prohibitive for small and medium-sized businesses, especially when integrating multiple components. Larger enterprises may find the investment worthwhile, but smaller companies might struggle to justify the expense.
Complex Setup and Configuration Setting up and configuring Salesforce Einstein can be complex, particularly for businesses without in-house technical expertise. The process involves integrating data, configuring settings, and training machine learning models, which can be time-consuming and require specialized knowledge.
Steep Learning Curve Despite its user-friendly interface, the breadth of features and tools available in Salesforce Einstein can be overwhelming for new users. There is a steep learning curve associated with understanding and effectively utilizing all of Einstein’s capabilities, which may require additional training and resources.
Data Dependency Einstein’s effectiveness depends heavily on the quality and volume of data available in Salesforce. Businesses with incomplete or poor-quality data may not realize the full potential of Einstein’s predictive analytics and machine learning capabilities. Ensuring data accuracy and completeness is crucial for optimal performance.
Integration Challenges While Einstein integrates seamlessly with Salesforce, integrating it with other external systems and data sources can be challenging. Businesses that rely on multiple platforms may face difficulties in achieving a unified view of their data, which can limit the effectiveness of Einstein’s insights.
Limited Customization Although Einstein offers a range of powerful features, some users have noted limitations in customization. Businesses with unique or complex requirements may find that Einstein’s out-of-the-box solutions do not fully meet their needs, necessitating additional customization or supplementary tools.
Who are the Competitors of Salesforce Einstein? Salesforce Einstein operates in a competitive landscape with several other notable AI and analytics platforms. Here are some of its main competitors:
IBM Watson Overview: IBM Watson is a leading AI platform offering a wide range of AI-powered tools and services, including natural language processing, machine learning, and predictive analytics.
Features: Watson provides advanced analytics, automated insights, and robust AI capabilities. It integrates with various data sources and offers extensive customization options.
Strengths: IBM Watson’s flexibility and powerful AI tools make it suitable for complex business needs. It is known for its robust natural language processing and deep learning capabilities.
Weaknesses: The complexity and cost of IBM Watson can be high, making it more suitable for large enterprises with substantial budgets.
Microsoft Azure AI Overview: Microsoft Azure AI offers a comprehensive suite of AI and machine learning services integrated within the Azure cloud platform.
Features: Azure AI provides tools for machine learning, natural language processing, computer vision, and more. It integrates seamlessly with other Microsoft products and services.
Strengths: Azure AI’s integration with the Azure cloud platform and other Microsoft tools makes it highly versatile. It offers scalable solutions for businesses of all sizes.
Weaknesses: The learning curve for Azure AI can be steep, and some users may find it challenging to navigate the extensive array of features and services.
Google Cloud AI Overview: Google Cloud AI provides a suite of machine learning and AI tools integrated with Google Cloud Platform.
Features: Google Cloud AI offers tools for natural language processing, machine learning, computer vision, and more. It benefits from Google’s extensive expertise in AI and data analytics.
Strengths: Google Cloud AI’s powerful tools and seamless integration with Google Cloud Platform make it a strong contender. It offers scalable and flexible solutions for various business needs.
Weaknesses: The cost of Google Cloud AI can be high, and some users may find the setup and configuration process complex.
SAP Leonardo Overview: SAP Leonardo is an AI and machine learning platform integrated with SAP’s enterprise solutions.
Features: SAP Leonardo provides tools for machine learning, IoT, blockchain, and more. It integrates seamlessly with SAP’s ERP systems and other enterprise solutions.
Strengths: SAP Leonardo’s integration with SAP’s enterprise solutions makes it highly suitable for businesses already using SAP products. It offers robust and comprehensive AI capabilities.
Weaknesses: The cost and complexity of SAP Leonardo can be high, and it may be less suitable for businesses not already using SAP’s enterprise solutions.
FAQs 1: What types of businesses can benefit from using Salesforce Einstein?
Answer: Salesforce Einstein is designed to benefit a wide range of businesses, from small startups to large enterprises. It is particularly useful for businesses that rely heavily on customer relationship management (CRM) and want to leverage AI to enhance their operations. Industries such as retail, finance, healthcare, manufacturing, and technology can all benefit from Einstein’s predictive analytics, automated insights, and machine learning capabilities. By integrating AI into their CRM, businesses can improve customer engagement, optimize sales and marketing strategies, and streamline operations.
2: How does Salesforce Einstein improve sales and marketing efforts?
Answer: Salesforce Einstein enhances sales and marketing efforts by providing predictive analytics and automated insights. For sales teams, Einstein offers predictive lead scoring, which helps prioritize leads that are most likely to convert. This enables sales representatives to focus their efforts on high-potential opportunities. For marketing teams, Einstein provides insights into customer behavior and preferences, allowing for more targeted and personalized marketing campaigns. Additionally, Einstein’s natural language processing capabilities can analyze customer feedback and sentiment, helping businesses tailor their messaging and improve customer satisfaction.
3: What is required to set up and integrate Salesforce Einstein with my existing Salesforce environment?
Answer: To set up and integrate Salesforce Einstein with your existing Salesforce environment, follow these steps:
Salesforce Account: Ensure you have an active Salesforce account. If not, sign up for one on the Salesforce website. Enable Einstein: Navigate to the Salesforce AppExchange and search for “Salesforce Einstein” components like Einstein Analytics, Einstein Discovery, or Einstein Voice. Install and enable these components in your Salesforce org. Configure Settings: Set up user permissions, define data access, and configure preferences for Einstein features. Salesforce provides guides and support for configuration. Data Integration: Ensure your Salesforce data is accurate and up-to-date. Import any additional data sources and integrate them into Salesforce. Train Models: For predictive analytics and machine learning, allow Einstein to analyze historical data and build models. Monitor and adjust the models as needed. Customize Dashboards: Create customized dashboards and reports to visualize insights and set up automated alerts for key metrics. 4: How much does Salesforce Einstein cost?
Answer: Salesforce Einstein offers a range of pricing plans based on the specific components and features chosen:
Einstein Analytics: Starts at $75 per user per month. Includes advanced analytics and customizable dashboards. Einstein Discovery: Starts at $150 per user per month. Provides automated data discovery and predictive analytics. Einstein Voice: Pricing available upon request. Enables voice-activated interactions and insights. Einstein Prediction Builder: Starts at $75 per user per month. Allows creation of custom AI models. Einstein Bots: Starts at $50 per user per month. Offers automated customer service interactions. Einstein Vision and Language: Pricing available upon request. Provides image recognition and NLP capabilities. The pricing may vary based on the specific needs and scale of the business. It’s recommended to contact Salesforce for detailed pricing and to discuss customized plans.
5: What support options are available for Salesforce Einstein users?
Answer: Salesforce offers a comprehensive range of support options for Einstein users:
Documentation and Tutorials: Extensive online resources, including user guides, tutorials, and best practices, are available on the Salesforce website. Trailhead: Salesforce’s interactive learning platform, Trailhead, offers modules and trails specifically focused on Einstein, helping users learn how to use its features effectively. Community Support: Salesforce has an active user community where users can ask questions, share knowledge, and get advice from other Salesforce users. Customer Support: Salesforce provides direct customer support through various channels, including phone, email, and live chat. Support plans vary based on the subscription level, with higher-tier plans offering more comprehensive support options. Consulting Services: For businesses needing more personalized assistance, Salesforce offers consulting services to help with implementation, customization, and optimization of Einstein features.
